awd_titl_txt: Conference on Measurement of Atmospheric Mercury: Assessment of New Measurement and Calibration Methods and Development of a Path Forward; Reno, Nevada; October 11-13, 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will bring together researchers that measure atmospheric mercury (Hg) in order to discuss existing benefits and limitations of current measurement and calibration methods and to suggest future needs for new measurement systems. There is recent community consensus that commercially available instruments that measure Hg have potential biases and this workshop will gather members of the Hg measurement community in order to discuss these biases and data gaps as well as work to create consensus on next steps and future needs.

The workshop has three primary objectives: (1) establish the current state of the science; (2) develop a consensus about the path forward; and (3) publish a peer-reviewed paper based on the workshop’s findings. Additionally, a report to NSF and a workshop white paper will be produced. The workshop will include presentations, hands-on demonstrations of measurement and calibration methods, and discussions oriented around the three primary objectives noted above. Invites will be sent to established researchers as well as graduate students, early career researchers, and underrepresented groups. The intellectual merit of this workshop includes a targeted discussion among the Hg measurement community on known biases and data gaps, as well as a focused effort to create community consensus on next steps and future needs. As for broader impacts, this workshop will strengthen Hg measurement community cohesion, and enhance graduate, early-career, and underrepresented researcher integration within the Hg measurement community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project entailed a conference/workshop that took place on the University of Nevada, Reno campus in October 2023. The focus was to bring together scientists that measure atmospheric mercury (Hg) to discuss the benefits and limitations of current measurement and calibration methods, as well as suggest needs for new measurement systems. Since the atmosphere is the pathway by which Hg is global distributed, making accurate, calibrated measurements is essential. There are pristine ecosystems with Hg fish consumption advisories contaminated by deposition of Hg from the atmosphere.

Mercury (Hg) researchers now know that HgII can represent 2 to 20% of total Hg in the atmosphere. This is important information, for HgII compounds are scrubbed from the air in precipitation and readily converted to methylmercury, the form that is bioaccumulated in food webs.

Major conclusions from the workshop include: because of our new knowledge regarding concentrations of atmospheric HgII, researchers should configure sampling systems to measure gaseous elemental Hg or total gaseous Hg, depending on the research objectives. The workshop discussions highlighted that current methods to measure gaseous oxidized and particulate-bound Hg have limitations and new methods need to be developed to make these measurements more accurate. It is quite difficult to measure the chemical composition of GOM compounds. Several methods are being developed. In order to make accurate measurements in the field, a GOM calibrator has been developed that has demonstrated to work well in the field. Current Hg monitoring networks that have relied on use of a KCl denuder for measurement of GOM need to reassess methods being used.

Intellectual merit

Through collaborative discussion occurring at the workshop, and shared knowledge, ways to improve measurements and alternate measurement methods were discussed. A manuscript was submitted to Environmental Science and Technology in January 2024 regarding the information developed at the workshop, allowing for broad dissemination of the developed information.

Broader impacts

The primary goal of this workshop was to bring members of the atmospheric Hg measurement community together to advance knowledge and work together as a unified team to reach a consensus regarding calibration and standard methods for atmospheric Hg measurements. Twenty-four atmospheric Hg scientists attended who are experts that have worked on developing new methods for atmospheric HgII measurement and calibration methods. This workshop provided a means to bring scientists from South Africa, Vietnam, China, Canada, England, and the United States to convene in one place. The scientists could then take the information developed back to their home countries and share it with their colleagues. It also allowed for students, postdoctoral researchers, and early career researchers to interact with senior scientists.

Better measurement systems are needed for atmospheric Hg. Accurate air Hg measurements are necessary to develop policies to reduce Hg pollution in the environment. Without calibrated measurements, monitoring network data are not reliable. Through this workshop, participants were exposed to new measurement methods being developed, and an international group of scientists presented on how new methods work and the data produced. Method limitations and needed improvements, and paths forward were discussed. With the Minamata Convention coming into force, there is a significant need to better understand the atmospheric pathway of Hg pollution, for it has been clearly demonstrated to be the dominant source of Hg to most ecosystems.
